content.description: The crux is working the moves up into the funnel at climb top although the climbing is sustained finger and hand jamming up to that point. This is maybe one of the best sustained and continuous finger and shallow hand cracks for the grade at the Devil's Lake... really no typical useable horizontals to grab nearby... straight in crack climbing all the way to the top.
content.protection: Excellent finger to shallow hand sized stoppers and cams.
content.location: Left side of the Main wall of Storm Wrack Wall and just left of the obvious 5.7 flake-corner-lieback climb- route #2 page 212 of 3rd Edition CGTDL (Swartling/Mayer).

content.description: Short, fun, and very height dependent. A cool one move wonder that might just make you smile.
content.location: Just up the hill from the Queen's Wave. Northwest end of the wall.

content.description: The name That's it says it all. By the time you finish the first move you are practically done with the climb. Climb crack until you can mantel on left ledge. Dont you the chimney on the left for your feet!
content.location: To the right of "Iceberg" and to the left of bootlegger and routes number 15, 16, 17. Between routes 14 and 15 in DL 3rd edition guide book.

content.description: Cool roof feature. Need someone to finish this thing off. Might be two lines?
content.protection: Thin pads, there are some dabby rocks.
content.location: Center of the wall, in the talus. There's a horn that sticks up which is quite visible from both sides, but the climb is hidden.

content.description: Cool feature with interesting slopers, pinches and an angled slab on the left. The top is slick!

Sustained lie-backing to horizontal but also utilizing outside edge of corner in two spots.  The left wall is slick but with just enough rough edge here and there.  This could be jammed straight in as well in top half where the width narrows to hand size otherwise starts out as hand stacking.  The top half of climb consists of very small side pulls and horizontals with feet established on the horizontal break the high stepping onto slopers to the top.
content.protection: Largercams in lower crack.  Mid sized cams at obvious horizontal.  Small stuff in top half.
content.location: This is the obvious left facing corner formed by a detached flake/block on the left side of the main wall of Storm Wrack Wall at Steinke Basin.  Rout #5 page 212 of 3rd Edition CGTDL (Swartling/Mayer).

content.description: This climb is hard to find if you are looking from the bottom of Storm wrack wall only because the crack is not visible until you get close to the climb. Climb flake to top.
content.location: Around the corner from route number 14 in the 3rd edition DL guide book.

content.description: This is a very very easy route and very short. Climb up the crack that leans inwards and you will be at the top before you know it. After the first lead the belayer decided he would follow in his boots and made it look to easy. Hence the name Bootlegger!
content.protection: Nuts to small cams. Can be set up as a top rope.
content.location: Furthest climb to the right if looking at Storm wrack wall. Right around the corner from route number 17 in the DL 3rd edition guide book. Would be considered route number 18.
